A member of one of the two groups of Ingrian Finns.

words.etymology_text: Named after Äyräpää: äyrämö- + -inen. Related to Ingrian ägrämöin.

glosses: bank (edge of river or lake)

words.etymology_text: From Proto-Finnic *äpräs, borrowed either from Proto-Germanic *auraz or from *ōferaz. Cognate with Karelian äpräs, Livvi äbräs and Ludian äbräz.

glosses: öre (one hundredth of the Swedish crown or krona)
øre (one hundredth of the Danish or Norwegian crown or krone)
eyrir (one hundreth of the Icelandic crown or króna)

examples.english: He's not going to inherit a red cent from me.

glosses: red cent (small amount of money)
Short for veroäyri.

categories: Finnish terms borrowed from Old Norse
Finnish terms derived from Old Norse
words.etymology_text: Borrowed from Old Norse eyrir (compare Swedish öre, Danish øre, Norwegian øre and Icelandic eyrir), from Latin aureus (“gold coin”).

glosses: bail (vessel to scoop water from a boat)
winnowing shovel

categories: Finnish terms derived from Old Norse
words.etymology_text: Front vowel variant of now rare auskari, borrowed from Old Norse ausker (“bail”) (compare Swedish öskar (“bail”)).

glosses: nominative plural of äyräs

raw_glosses: (taxation, archaic) In municipal taxation, the number of veroäyri's which a taxpayer must pay.
glosses: In municipal taxation, the number of veroäyri's which a taxpayer must pay.

raw_glosses: (literally) An amount of öre, øre or eyrir.
glosses: An amount of öre, øre or eyrir.

examples.text: Hän äyskäisi minulle, kun tein pienen virheen.

examples.english: The salary of the priests was determined according to a rating system.

words.etymology_text: äyrämöinen (“Finnish-speaking group of people in Ingria”) + murre (“dialect”)
